issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: The problem is a duplicate of an existing issue.

fields.summary: Restart of cloud controller in HA can cause deadlock

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
Steps followed:
- CLC *A* (10.111.5.18) is enabled
- CLC *B* (10.111.5.17) is disabled
- rebooted CLC *A*

After a while when CLC *A* stopped syncing, CLC *B* thinks it's still syncing (as in the log).

From CLC *B*,
{noformat}
[root@h-18 ~]# euca-describe-services
SERVICE	tokens         	eucalyptus     	10.111.5.18    	ENABLED   	221 	http://10.111.5.18:8773/services/Tokens 	arn:euca:eucalyptus::tokens:10.111.5.18/
SERVICE	autoscaling    	autoscaling    	10.111.5.18    	DISABLED  	221 	http://10.111.5.18:8773/services/AutoScaling	arn:euca:eucalyptus:autoscaling:autoscaling:10.111.5.18/

started=1382046437955 [/10.111.5.17]] for caller:

fields.summary: after rebooting the primary CLC, both CLCs stopped accepting requests
fields.environment:
2x CLC/W
2x CC00/SC00
2x CC01/SC01/VB
2x NC00
2x NC01 (ESXi)

Netapp cluster mode, multipathing enabled

comments.body: I tried to reproduce with a reboot of an enabled HA CLC but was unable to do so.

Workaround:
- stopped the secondary cloud (10.111.5.18) which has the disabled.lock file
- tried to restart the eucalyptus-cloud process on the enabled cloud (10.111.5.17), it was showing the legacy error,
{{CRITICAL: this is most likely a bug; to kill processes (THIS MAY CAUSE DATA LOSS) run: kill -9 1611  1610}},
so killed the eucalyptus-cloud process and postgres processes (with EUCA-6375 fix, it should be okay if we don't kill  postgres, correct me if I am wrong).
- after the primary cloud was enabled, started the secondary cloud (10.111.5.18).
- CLCs started to response

- Tried to describe autoscaling groups, found the following:
{noformat}
2013-10-17 22:53:13 DEBUG 000000854 DnsResolvers             | DnsResolver: A autoscaling.h-17.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com.
2013-10-17 22:53:13 DEBUG 000000854 DnsResolvers             | DnsResolver: failed for autoscaling.h-17.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com. using TopologyDnsResolver because of: Failed to lookup ENABLED service of type AutoScaling.
java.util.NoSuchElementException: Failed to lookup ENABLED service of type AutoScaling.
	at com.eucalyptus.component.Topology.lookup(Topology.java:913)
	at com.eucalyptus.component.TopologyDnsResolver.lookupRecords(TopologyDnsResolver.java:273)
	at com.eucalyptus.util.dns.DnsResolvers.lookupRecords(DnsResolvers.java:448)
	at com.eucalyptus.util.dns.DnsResolvers.findRecords(DnsResolvers.java:514)
	at com.eucalyptus.cloud.ws.ConnectionHandler.addAnswer(ConnectionHandler.java:287)
	at com.eucalyptus.cloud.ws.ConnectionHandler.generateReply(ConnectionHandler.java:198)
	at com.eucalyptus.cloud.ws.UDPHandler.run(UDPHandler.java:136)
{noformat}

At this point, two CLCs have two different knowledge about the services.

*Enabled CLC - 10.111.5.17*
{noformat}
[root@h-17 eucalyptus_iam]# euca-describe-services

- stopped the Disabled CLC, tried to describe AS group, still can't find the enabled AS service.
- restarted the Enabled cloud, still the same auto scaling group error,
{noformat}
2013-10-17 23:03:39 DEBUG 000000867 DnsResolvers             | DnsResolver: failed for autoscaling.h-17.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com. using TopologyDnsResolver because of: Failed to lookup ENABLED service of type AutoScaling.
{noformat}

The system on which the issue occurs seems OK now (after restarting a CLC and fixing the corrupt postgres transaction log)

This looks like EUCA-7141, though this cannot be confirmed now the system is back up.
